questions.text: Weakness of the extraocular muscles is seen in all of the following EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thyrotoxicosis Weakness of the muscle is not seen rather ocular motility is restricted . Restrictive myopathy- ocular motility is restricted initially by edema and later by fibrosis leading to diplopia, squint and loss of bell s phenomenon The sequence of involvement is IR, MR, SR, LR (IMSR) The earliest restriction is usually of elevation due to contracture of IR followed by abduction restriction Compressive optic neuropathy leads to visual loss

Highyeild:

Graves disease is the most common cause of unilateral and bilateral proptosis in adults It may occur in patients who are hyperthyroid, euthyroid, or hypothyroid Pathogenesis- It is an autoimmune ( type II) disorder in which antibodies produce the following changes Inflammation and enlargement of the extraocular muscles followed by fibrosis leading to compressive and restrictive myopathy Infiltration of inflammatory cells in orbital fat Clinical features- Soft tissue signs - periorbital and lid edema with conjunctival injection ( Goldzeiher’s sign earliest sign), chemosis and superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis The earliest symptoms are excessive lacrimation, grittiness and photophobia Proptosis - exophthalmos - axial, non-pulsatile- 2 nd most common sign leads to exposure keratitis Rx- Lubricating drops Botox to Muller's muscle Systemic steroids Orbital decompression

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Fisher Syndrome : Miller Fisher syndrome (MFS) is a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome and is characterised by a clinical triad of ophthalmoplegia , ataxia and areflexia Option: B . Myasthenia Gravis: Ocular myasthenia gravis only affects the muscles that move the eyes and eyelids. The symptoms of ocular myasthenia gravis include double vision and drooping eyelids . Option: C. Eaton-Lambert Syndrome: Ophthalmic manifestations of LEMS include ptosis and diplopia but unlike myasthenia gravis (MG), ocular and bulbar weakness presents late rather than early in the disease.

Extraedge:

Difference B/W Lems And Myasthenia Gravis Effect LEMS MG Muscles Proximal limb weakness (legs > arms) Exercise improves strength Muscle pain common Reflexes absent or decrease Extraocular, bulbar, and facial muscle weakness Fatigue with exercise Muscle pain uncommon Reflexes normal Gender Male > female Female > male Coexisting pathology Small cell carcinoma of the lung Thymoma Succinylcholine Sensitive Resistant Nondepolarizing muscle relaxants Sensitive Sensitive AChE agents Decreased (poor) response Good response

questions.text: The secondary action of the superior rectus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intorsion Superior Rectus : Primary action is Elevation. Secondary action : Adduction and Intorsion . Muscle Primary Secondary Tertiary Medial rectus Adduction Lateral rectus Abduction Inferior rectus Depression Excyclotorsion Adduction Superior rectus Elevation Incyclotorsion Adduction Inferior oblique Excyclotorsion Elevation Adduction Superior oblique Incyclotorsion Depression Adduction

Highyeild:

EXTRAOCULAR MUSCLES OF THE EYE: 6 Extraocular Muscles for movement of the eyeball. The Inferior, medial, lateral, and superior recti( 4 Recti) The superior and inferior oblique muscles. (2 Oblique) Superior Rectus Attachments : Originates from the superior part of the common tendinous ring, and attaches to the superior and anterior aspect of the sclera. Actions : The main movement is elevation . Also contributes to adduction and medial rotation of the eyeball. Inferior Rectus Attachments : Originates from the inferior part of the common tendinous ring, and attaches to the inferior and anterior aspect of the sclera. Actions : The main movement is depression . Also contributes to the adduction and lateral rotation of the eyeball Medial Rectus Attachments : Originates from the medial part of the common tendinous ring, and attaches to the anteromedial aspect of the sclera. Actions : Adducts the eyeball Lateral Rectus : Attachment s: Originates from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring, and attaches to the anterolateral aspect of the sclera. Actions : Abducts the eyeball. Oblique Muscles There are two oblique muscles – the superior and inferior obliques. From their origin, the oblique muscles take an angular approach to the eyeball. They attach to the posterior surface of the sclera. Superior Oblique: Attachments : Originates from the body of the sphenoid bone. Its tendon passes through a trochlea and then attaches to the sclera of the eye, posterior to the superior rectus. Actions : Depresses , abducts and medially rotates the eyeball. Inferior Oblique : Attachments : Originates from the anterior aspect of the orbital floor. Attaches to the sclera of the eye, posterior to the lateral rectus Actions : Elevates , abducts and laterally rotates the eyeball. NERVE SUPPLY: SO4,LR6 REST BY 3RD NERVE: Superior oblique : Trochlear nerve Lateral rectus : Abducens nerve Rest by: oculomotor (III nerve.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: C . The primary action of the superior and inferior rectus are elevation and depression respectively. Option: B . The primary action of superior and inferior oblique are intorsion and extortion respectively. The secondary action of the superior rectus is intorsion and extortion is the secondary action of the inferior rectus. Option: D . Superior oblique causes depression as the secondary action and inferior oblique causes elevation as the secondary action. Both the recti cause adduction as tertiary action and obliques cause abduction as tertiary action. The medial and lateral rectus has only primary action with no secondary and tertiary action.

Extraedge:

The extraocular muscles are innervated by three cranial nerves. Damage to one of the cranial nerves will cause paralysis of its respective muscles. This will alter the resting gaze of the affected eye. Thus, a lesion of each cranial nerve has its own characteristic appearance : The Oculomotor nerve (CN III) – A lesion of the oculomotor nerve affects most of the extraocular muscles. The affected eye is displaced laterally by the lateral rectus and inferiorly by the superior oblique. The eye adopts a position known as ‘down and out’. The Trochlear nerve (CN IV) – A lesion of CN IV will paralyse the superior oblique muscle. There is no obvious effect of the resting orientation of the eyeball. However, the patient will complain of diplopia (double vision) and may develop a head tilt away from the site of the lesion. The Abducens nerve (CN VI) – A lesion of CN VI will paralyse the lateral rectus muscle. The affected eye will be adducted by the resting tone of the medial rectus

questions.text: You are sitting in an OPD as an intern with a Junior resident and attending the patient. Your junior resident asks you to examine the eye movements of a 28-year-old male. While examining, the person moves the eyes as commanded by you. Which of the following muscles will not be included in this category of muscles?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inferior tarsal In the given question, the description given describes the voluntary groups of muscles which move on the will of the patient. All of the above-given options are voluntary groups of muscles except the inferior tarsal.

Highyeild:

Involuntary Muscles of the Eye: Tarsal Muscles (Superior And Inferior) Levator Palpebrae Superioris Voluntry Muscles of the Eye: The Inferior, medial, lateral, and superior recti( 4 Recti) The superior and inferior oblique muscles. (2 Oblique) Examination of Examination of Ocular Movements:: Making H with a digit to check extraocular movements.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- The muscles in other options are a voluntary group of muscles. Option:A.Superior Rectus Option:B. Inferior rectus Option:C.Superior oblique

Extraedge:

Levator Palpebrae Superioris The levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) is the only muscle involved in raising the superior eyelid. A small portion of this muscle contains a collection of smooth muscle fibres – known as the superior tarsal muscle. In contrast to the LPS, the superior tarsal muscle is innervated by the sympathetic nervous system . Attachments : Originates from the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone, immediately above the optic foramen. It attaches to the superior tarsal plate of the upper eyelid (a thick plate of connective tissue). Actions: Elevates the upper eyelid . Innervation: The levator palpebrae superioris is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (CN III) . The superior tarsal muscle (located within the LPS) is innervated by the sympathetic nervous system.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the movement of the eye is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Movement around the horizontal axis of the eye in one eye is referred to as adduction and abduction.

options.label: B
options.text: Movement around the vertical axis of the eye in one eye is referred to as elevation and depression.

options.label: C
options.text: Movement around the anteroposterior axis will be defined as intorsion and extortion.

questions.correct_answer: C. Movement around the anteroposterior axis will be defined as intorsion and extortion.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Movement around the anteroposterior axis will be defined as intorsion and extortion. The movement of the eye around the three axes can be defined as- Movement around the vertical axis of the eye in one eye is referred to as adduction and abduction . (hence, option B is wrong) Movement around the horizontal axis of the eye in one eye is referred to as elevation and depression . (hence option A is wrong) Movement around the anteroposterior axis will be defined as intorsion and extorsion . (option C is correct)

Highyeild:

The movements possible for the eyeball are elevation, depression, adduction, abduction, intorsion, and extorsion. These movements occur along three axes, i.e., transverse, vertical, and anteroposterior. 1. Movement around the vertical axis of the eye in one eye is referred to as adduction and abduction . 2. Movement around the horizontal axis of the eye in one eye is referred to as elevation and depression. 3. Movement around the anteroposterior axis will be defined as intorsion and extorsion .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Movement around the vertical axis of the eye in one eye is referred to as adduction and abduction . Option: B. Movement around the horizontal axis of the eye in one eye is referred to as elevation and depression.

Extraedge:

Axes and Movemnts of the Eye:

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presented with left eye hypertropia. On looking to the right, the deviation in the eye increased. After tilting the head to the left, the deviation also increased. The affected muscle was identified to be left superior oblique. What is the angle made with the optical axis at which it is inserted?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

51 degree In the given question, the muscle identified after the park three-step test is left superior oblique. Both the obliques are tilted at 51 degrees before their insertion. Hence the correct answer will be option B.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . 23 degrees. Both the superior and the inferior rectus are inserted at 23 degrees to the optical axis of the eye. Hence, they cause elevation and depression in the abducted eye. Option s: C and D . Do not represent any relation to the angle for extraocular muscle.

questions.text: During your anatomy lecture on superior orbital fissures, you observe the following image showing the common tendinous ring of Zinn as given below. Which of the following muscles does not originate from this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inferior Oblique In the given question, as asked, the muscle which does not originate from the common tendinous ring of zinn is inferior oblique. It arises from the orbital surface of the maxilla from the floor of the orbit. All recti muscles (option B, C, D) originate from the common tendinous ring of zinn and insert in front of the equator of the eyeball and behind the sclera-corneal junction.

Highyeild:

Annulus Of Zinn ( Tendinous Ring ) Tendinous Ring gives origin to all the rectus muscles and levator palpebrae superioris(LPS). Superior Rectus originates from the superior part of the common tendinous ring. Inferior Rectus originates from the inferior part of the common tendinous ring. Medial Rectus originates from the medial part of the common tendinous ring. Lateral Rectus originates from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Inferior rectus - originates from the common tendinous ring of Zinn Option: C . Lateral rectus - originates from the common tendinous ring of Zinn Option: D . Medial rectus - originates from the common tendinous ring of Zinn

Extraedge:

Contents of superior and inferior orbital fissures.

questions.text: During the examination of an 8-year-old child during the ophthalmology OPD, you observe that the child is not able to perform adduction movement of the right eye. According to the clinical anatomy and nerve supply of the EOM, which of the following muscles is supplied by different nerves other than the muscle mentioned in the question?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lateral Rectus. In the given clinical scenario, as mentioned the child is not able to perform the adduction movement of the right eye i.e. the muscle involved is the medial rectus of the right eye . It is supplied by the oculomotor nerve. The lateral rectus is supplied by the abducens nerve. The superior oblique is supplied by the trochlear nerve. So, the correct answer is option A.

Highyeild:

Muscles supplied by the oculomotor nerve are- Superior rectus (option C) Inferior rectus Levator palpebrae superioris (option D) Inferior oblique. (option B) Medial Rectus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- All of the following are supplied by the oculomotor nerve. Option: B. Inferior oblique Option: C. Superior rectus Option: D. Levator palpebrae superioris

Extraedge:

Horner’s syndrome refers to a triad of symptoms produced by damage to the sympathetic trunk in the neck due to causes such as a tumour of the apex of the lung (Pancoast tumour) , aortic aneurysm or thyroid carcinoma. Partial ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) – Due to denervation of the superior tarsal muscle. Miosis (pupillary constriction) – Due to denervation of the dilator pupillae muscle. Anhidrosis (absence of sweating) on the ipsilateral side of the face – Due to denervation of the sweat glands.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came with the complaint of restriction in eye movements - he has a problem seeing downward in the right direction. With the help of your knowledge of conjugate movements of the eye, which of the following pair of muscles will be affected?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

RIR and LSO In the given question, the patient has a problem seeing downward in the right direction e. dextro-depression , so the pair of muscles involved in this movement is RIR and LSO. Hence the appropriate answer will be option C.

Highyeild:

Conjugate eye movements are those that preserve the angular relationship between the right and left eyes. For example, when you move both eyes left and then right, a conjugate movement is made. Up and down movements and combinations of vertical and lateral movements also fall into the conjugate category

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . RIR and RIO do not lead to dextro-depression. They are both importers but differ in function of depression and elevation respectively. Option: B . LIO and RSR- helps in dextroelevation. Option: D. LIR and RSO- both these muscles help in Levo-depression.

Extraedge:

Horizontal gaze pathway ' When the PPRF lesion is located rostrally to the abducens nucleus, ipsilateral paralysis of the horizontal conjugate gaze occurs, including both saccadic and pursuit eye movements . Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is a condition caused by a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), a fibre tract responsible for transmitting information that is vital for the coordination of different eye movements
